Computing bounds under non-constant treatment effect

Keaven M. Anderson

Source: vignettes/articles/story-compute-npe-bound.Rmd
story-compute-npe-bound.Rmd

Overview

We consider group sequential designs with possibly non-constant treatment effects over time. This can be useful for situations such as an assumed non-proportional hazards model as laid out in vignettes/articles/story-npe-background.Rmd. In general, we assume K≥1K \geq 1 analyses with statistical information ℐk\mathcal{I}_k and information fraction tk=ℐk/ℐkt_k=\mathcal{I}_k/\mathcal{I}_k at analysis kk, 1≤k≤K1\leq k\leq K. We denote the null hypothesis H0H_{0}: θ(t)=0\theta(t)=0 and an alternate hypothesis H1H_1: θ(t)=θ1(t)\theta(t)=\theta_1(t) for t>0t> 0 where tt represents the information fraction for a study. While a study is planned to stop at information fraction t=1t=1, we define θ(t)\theta(t) for t>0t>0 since a trial can overrun its planned statistical information at the final analysis. As before, we use a shorthand notation in to have θ\theta represent θ()\theta(), θ=0\theta=0 to represent θ(t)≡0\theta(t)\equiv 0 for all tt and θ1\theta_1 to represent θi(tk)\theta_i(t_k), the effect size at analysis kk, 1≤k≤K1\leq k\leq K.

For our purposes, H0H_0 will represent no treatment difference, but it could represent a non-inferiority hypothesis. Recall that we assume KK analyses and bounds −∞≤ak<bk<≤∞-\infty \leq a_k< b_k<\leq \infty for 1≤k<K1\leq k < K and −∞≤aK≤bK<∞-\infty \leq a_K\leq b_K<\infty. We denote the probability of crossing the upper boundary at analysis kk without previously crossing a bound by

αk(θ)=Pθ({Zk≥bk}∩j=1k−1{aj≤Zj<bj}),\alpha_{k}(\theta)=P_{\theta}(\{Z_{k}\geq b_{k}\}\cap_{j=1}^{k-1}\{a_{j}\leq Z_{j}< b_{j}\}),k=1,2,…,K.k=1,2,\ldots,K. The total probability of crossing an upper bound prior to crossing a lower bound is denoted by

α(θ)≡∑k=1Kαk(θ).\alpha(\theta)\equiv\sum_{k=1}^K\alpha_k(\theta).

For non-binding bounds, we define the probability

αk+(θ)=Pθ{{Zk≥bk}∩j=1k−1{Zj<bj}}\alpha_{k}^{+}(\theta)=P_{\theta}\{\{Z_{k}\geq b_{k}\}\cap_{j=1}^{k-1} \{Z_{j}< b_{j}\}\} which ignores the lower bounds when computing upper boundary crossing probabilities. The non-binding Type I error is the probability of ever crossing the upper bound when θ=0\theta=0. The value αk+(0)\alpha^+_{k}(0) is commonly referred to as the amount of Type I error spent at analysis kk, 1≤k≤K1\leq k\leq K. The total upper boundary crossing probability for a trial is denoted in this one-sided scenario by α+(θ)≡∑k=1Kαk+(θ).\alpha^+(\theta) \equiv\sum_{k=1}^{K}\alpha^+_{k}(\theta). We will primarily be interested in α(θ)\alpha(\theta) to compute power when θ>0\theta > 0. For Type I error, we may be interested in α(0)\alpha(0) for binding lower bounds, but more often we will consider non-binding Type I error calculations, α+(0)\alpha^{+}(0).

We denote the probability of crossing a lower bound at analysis kk without previously crossing any bound by

βk(θ)=Pθ((Zk<ak}∩j=1k−1{aj≤Zj<bj}).\beta_{k}(\theta)=P_{\theta}((Z_{k}< a_{k}\}\cap_{j=1}^{k-1}\{ a_{j}\leq Z_{j}< b_{j}\}).

Efficacy bounds bkb_k, 1≤k≤K1\leq k\leq K, for a group sequential design will be derived to control Type I at some level α=α(0)\alpha=\alpha(0).

Lower bounds aka_k, 1≤k≤K1\leq k\leq K may be used to control boundary crossing probabilities under either the null hypothesis (2-sided testing), the alternate hypothesis or some other hypothesis (futility testing).

Thus, we may consider up to 3 values of θ(t)\theta(t):

  • under the null hypothesis θ0(t)=0\theta_0(t)=0 for computing efficacy bounds,
  • under a value θ1(t)\theta_1(t) for computing lower bounds, and
  • under a value θa(t)\theta_a(t) for computing sample size or power.

We refer to the information under these 3 assumptions as ℐ(0)(t)\mathcal{I}^{(0)}(t), ℐ(1)(t)\mathcal{I}^{(1)}(t), and ℐ(a)(t)\mathcal{I}^{(a)}(t), respectively. Often we will assume ℐ(t)=ℐ(0)(t)=ℐ(1)(t)=ℐ(a)(t).\mathcal{I}(t)=\mathcal{I}^{(0)}(t)=\mathcal{I}^{(1)}(t)=\mathcal{I}^{(a)}(t).

We note that information may differ under different values of θ(t)\theta(t). For fixed designs, Lachin (2009) computes sample size based on different variances under the null and alternate hypothesis.

Spending bounds

We consider different boundary types in the gsDesign package and simplify them into two types according to whether lower bounds are binding or non-binding. The concept is to implicitly derive Z-value bounds ak,bk,k=1,⋯,Ka_k, b_k, k=1,\cdots,K based on probabilities specified in the following table. We include the test.type argument from the gsDesign::gsDesign() function for reference.

Boundary crossing probabilities used to set Z-value boundaries
test.type Upper bound Lower bound Design type
1 αk+(0)\alpha_k^{+}(0) None One-sided efficacy
2 αk(0)\alpha_k(0) αk(0)\alpha_k(0) 2-sided symmetric
3 αk(0)\alpha_k(0) βk(θa)\beta_k(\theta_a) β\beta-spending with binding futility
4 αk+(0)\alpha_k^{+}(0) βk(θa)\beta_k(\theta_a) β\beta-spending with non-binding futility
5 αk(0)\alpha_k(0) βi(θ1)\beta_i(\theta_1) θ\theta-spending with binding futility
6 α+(0)\alpha^{+}(0) βi(θ1)\beta_i(\theta_1) θ\theta-spending with non-binding futility

This can be reduced to just two types distinguishing by whether or not lower bounds are binding or non-binding:

Reduced options for boundary crossing probabilities used to set Z-value boundaries
test.type Upper bound Lower bound Design type
2, 3, 5 αk(0)\alpha_k(0) βk(θ)\beta_k(\theta) Binding lower bound
1, 4, 6 αk+(0)\alpha_k^{+}(0) βk(θ)\beta_k(\theta) Non-binding lower bound

In this second table we have used θ=0\theta=0 to derive the upper bound to control Type I error in all cases. We have chosen some arbitrary θ\theta which could be 0 for any other test.type, θa\theta_a for β\beta-spending or some arbitrary θ1\theta_1 otherwise. We note that for a one-sided design we let βk(θ)=0\beta_k(\theta)=0 so that ak=−∞,k=1,⋯,Ka_k=-\infty, k=1,\cdots,K. For test.type=3, 4 we let θ=θa\theta=\theta_a, while for test.type=5, 6 θ≥0\theta \geq 0 is arbitrary. We note that asymmetric α\alpha-spending bounds can be derived using test.type > 2 and θ=0.\theta=0.

Two-sided testing and design

We denote an alternative HaH_{a}: θ(t)=θa(t)\theta(t)=\theta_a(t); we will always assume HaH_a for power calculations; when using β\beta-spending we will also use HaH_a for controlling lower boundary aka_k crossing probabilities by letting θ=θa\theta=\theta_a for lower bound spending. A value of θ(t)>0\theta(t)>0 will reflect a positive benefit. We will not restrict the alternate hypothesis to θa(t)>0\theta_a(t)>0 for all tt. The value of θ(t)\theta(t) will be referred to as the (standardized) treatment effect at information fraction tt.

We assume there is interest in stopping early if there is good evidence to reject one hypothesis in favor of the other.

If ak=−∞a_k= -\infty at analysis kk for some 1≤k≤K1\leq k\leq K then the alternate hypothesis cannot be rejected at analysis kk; i.e., there is no futility bound at analysis kk. For k=1,2,…,Kk=1,2,\ldots,K, the trial is stopped at analysis kk to reject H0H_0 if aj<Zj<bja_j<Z_j< b_j, j=1,2,…,i−1j=1,2,\dots,i-1 and Zk≥bkZ_k\geq b_k. If the trial continues until stage kk without crossing a bound and Zk≤akZ_k\leq a_k then H1H_1 is rejected in favor of H0H_0, k=1,2,…,Kk=1,2,\ldots,K. Note that if aK<bKa_K< b_K there is the possibility of completing the trial without rejecting H0H_0 or H1H_1 unless aK=bK.a_K=b_K.

Haybittle-Peto and spending bounds

The recursive algorithm of the previous section allows computation of both spending bounds and Haybittle-Peto bounds. For a Haybittle-Peto efficacy bound, one would normally set bk=Φ−1(1−ϵ)b_k=\Phi^{-1}(1-\epsilon) for k=1,2,…,K−1k=1,2,\ldots,K-1 and some small ϵ>0\epsilon>0 such as ϵ=0.001\epsilon= 0.001 which yields bk=3.09b_k=3.09. While the original proposal was to use bK=Φ−1(1−α)b_K=\Phi^{-1}(1-\alpha) at the final analysis, to fully control one-sided Type I error at level α\alpha we suggest computing the final bound bKb_K using the above algorithm so that α(0)=α\alpha(0)=\alpha.

Bounds computed with spending αk(0)\alpha_k(0) at analysis kk can be computed by using equation (9) for b1b_1. Then for k=2,…,Kk=2,\ldots,K the algorithm of the previous section is used. As noted by Jennison and Turnbull (1999), b1,…,bKb_1,\ldots,b_K if determined under the null hypothesis depend only on tkt_k and αk(0)\alpha_k(0) with no dependence on ℐk\mathcal{I}_k, k=1,…,Kk=1,\ldots,K. When computing bounds based on βk(θ)\beta_k(\theta), k=1,…,Kk=1,\ldots,K, where some θ(tk)≠0\theta(t_k)\neq 0 we have an additional dependency with aka_k depending not only on tkt_k and bkb_k, k=1,…,Kk=1,\ldots,K, but also on the final total information ℐK\mathcal{I}_K. Thus, a spending bound under something other than the null hypothesis needs to be recomputed each time ℐK\mathcal{I}_K changes, whereas it only needs to be computed once when θ(tk)=0\theta(t_k)=0, k=1,…,Kk=1,\ldots,K.

Bounds based on boundary families

Assume constants b1*,…,bK*b_1^*,\ldots,b_K^* and a total targeted one-sided Type I error α\alpha. We wish to find CuC_u as a function of t1,…tKt_1,\ldots t_K such that if bk=Cubk*b_k=C_ub_k^* then α(0)=α.\alpha(0)=\alpha. Thus, the problem is to solve for CuC_u. If aka_k, k=1,2,…,Kk=1,2,\ldots,K are fixed then this is a simple root finding problem. Since one normally normally uses non-binding efficacy bounds, it will normally be the case that ak=−∞a_k=-\infty, k=1,…,Kk=1,\ldots,K for this problem.

Now we assume constants ak*a_k^* and wish to find ClC_l such that if ak=Clak*+θ(tk)ℐka_k=C_la_k^*+\theta(t_k)\sqrt{\mathcal{I}_k} for k=1,…,Kk=1,\ldots,K then β(θ)=β\beta(\theta)=\beta. If we use the constant upper bounds from the previous paragraph, finding ClC_l is a simple root-finding problem.

For 2-sided symmetric bounds with ak=−bka_k=-b_k, k=1,…,Kk=1,\ldots,K, we only need to solve for CuC_u and again use simple root finding.

At this point, we do not solve for this type of bound for asymmetric upper and lower bounds.

Sample size

For sample size, we assume tkt_k, and θ(tk)\theta(t_k)1,…,K1,\ldots,K are fixed. We assume β(θ)\beta(\theta) is decreasing as ℐ\mathcal{I} is decreasing. This will automatically be the case when θ(tk)>0\theta(t_k)>0, k=1,…,Kk=1,\ldots,K and for many other cases. Thus, the information required is done by a search for ℐ𝒦\mathcal{I_K} that yields α(θ)\alpha(\theta) yields the targeted power.

References

Jennison, Christopher, and Bruce W Turnbull. 1999. Group Sequential Methods with Applications to Clinical Trials. Chapman & Hall/CRC.
Lachin, John M. 2009. Biostatistical Methods: The Assessment of Relative Risks. John Wiley & Sons.
